request.description:
**Summary**  
User registration endpoint for the Blog REST API – Internship Project.

---

This endpoint creates a new user account in the Blog REST API. Use it when a new user signs up and you want to store their credentials (username and password) along with their email address. On success, it returns the created user’s public details.

---

## Request

- **Method:** `POST`
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/register/`

### Required Headers
- `Content-Type: application/json`

### Request Body (JSON)

```json
{
  "username": "mahan",
  "password": "mahan@123",
  "email": "mahan@example.com"
}
```

**Fields**
- `username` (`string`, required) – Unique username for the new user.  
  Example: `"mahan"`
- `password` (`string`, required) – Password for the new user account.  
  Example: `"mahan@123"`
- `email` (`string`, required) – Email address of the user.  
  Example: `"mahan@example.com"`

---

## Response

### 201 Created
Returned when the user is successfully registered.

**Sample Response Body**

```json
{
  "username": "mahan",
  "email": "mahan@example.com"
}
```

The password is not returned in the response for security reasons.

request.description:
Retrieves a list of blog posts.

**Method:** `GET`
**URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts`

### Response
On success, this endpoint returns `200 OK` with a JSON array of post objects. Each post has the following fields (based on the latest 200 OK response):

```json
[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "title": "My family photo",
    "content": "This my family photo",
    "comments": [
      {
        "content": "nice family"
      }
    ],
    "author": 2,
    "created_at": "2025-12-10T10:30:56Z",
    "updated_at": "2025-12-10T10:31:07.425693Z"
  }
]
```

### Field descriptions
- `id` (integer): Unique identifier for the blog post.
- `title` (string): Title of the blog post.
- `content` (string): Main text content of the post.
- `comments` (array): List of comment objects associated with the post.
  - `content` (string): Text of the comment.
- `author` (integer): Identifier of the user who created the post.
- `created_at` (string, ISO 8601 datetime): Timestamp when the post was created.
- `updated_at` (string, ISO 8601 datetime): Timestamp when the post was last updated.

request.description:
### Get a single blog post by ID

Retrieve the details of a single blog post, including its comments and metadata.

**Method:** `GET`  
**URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts/:id`

#### Path parameters
- `id` (integer, required): Unique identifier of the post to retrieve.

#### Authentication
If your API requires authentication for this endpoint, make sure the correct auth mechanism is configured at the collection or request level (e.g., Bearer token). This request itself does not define auth settings explicitly.

#### Sample request
```http
GET http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts/1
Content-Type: application/json
```

#### Successful response (200)
Returns a JSON object with the post data and its comments.

**Response body example:**
```json
{
  "id": 1,
  "title": "My family photo",
  "content": "This my family photo",
  "comments": [
    { "content": "nice family" }
  ],
  "author": 2,
  "created_at": "2025-12-10T10:30:56Z",
  "updated_at": "2025-12-10T10:31:07.425693Z"
}
```

#### Response schema
- `id` (integer): Unique identifier of the post.
- `title` (string): Title of the blog post.
- `content` (string): Main content/body of the blog post.
- `comments` (array of objects): List of comments associated with this post.
  - `content` (string): Text of the comment.
- `author` (integer): ID of the user who created the post.
- `created_at` (string, date-time): When the post was created (ISO 8601 format).
- `updated_at` (string, date-time): When the post was last updated (ISO 8601 format).

request.description:
## Purpose
Create a new blog post. Only authenticated/authorized users are allowed to create posts.

## URL & Method
- **Method:** `POST`
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts`

## Authentication
- This endpoint requires a valid access token.
- Include the token in the `Authorization` header as a Bearer token.
- Example:
  ```http
  Authorization: Bearer <your_jwt_access_token>
  ```

## Request Headers
- `Content-Type: application/json`
- `Authorization: Bearer <your_jwt_access_token>`

## Request Body
Send a JSON object with the following fields:

| Field    | Type   | Required | Description              | Example           |
|---------|--------|----------|--------------------------|-------------------|
| `title` | string | yes      | Title of the blog post   | "testing post"   |
| `content` | string | yes    | Main content of the post | "tested"         |

### Sample Request Body
```json
{
  "title": "testing post",
  "content": "tested"
}
```

> Note: Other valid sample values (based on known usage) include:
> - `title`: "testing 2", "just testing"
> - `content`: "done", "Done"

## Successful Response (201 Created)
On success, the API returns HTTP **201 Created** with the newly created post object.

### Sample 201 Response
```json
{
  "id": 7,
  "title": "testing post",
  "content": "tested",
  "comments": [],
  "author": 4,
  "created_at": "2025-12-19T12:11:50.653261Z",
  "updated_at": "2025-12-19T12:11:50.653261Z"
}
```

### Response Fields
- `id` (integer): Unique identifier of the post.
- `title` (string): Title of the created post.
- `content` (string): Content of the created post.
- `comments` (array): List of comments associated with the post (empty when first created).
- `author` (integer): ID of the user who created the post.
- `created_at` (string, ISO 8601): Timestamp when the post was created.
- `updated_at` (string, ISO 8601): Timestamp when the post was last updated.

This endpoint creates a new blog post resource.

- **Method:** `POST`
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts`
- **Authentication:** JWT Bearer token is required.
  - Include the token in the `Authorization` header:
    ```http
    Authorization: Bearer <your_jwt_access_token>
    ```

#### Request Headers
- `Content-Type: application/json`
- `Authorization: Bearer <your_jwt_access_token>`

#### Request Body
Send a JSON object with the following fields:

```json
{
  "title": "My family photo",
  "content": "Done"
}
```

- `title` (string, required): The title of the blog post. Example: `"My family photo"`.
- `content` (string, required): The main content/body of the blog post. Example: `"Done"`.

#### Expected Behavior
- On success (authenticated request with valid data), a new blog post is created.
- If authentication is missing or invalid, the API returns `401 Unauthorized` with a message similar to:
  ```json
  {
    "detail": "Authentication credentials were not provided."
  ```

request.description:
Updates an existing blog post by its unique ID.
Only the post's user can updated
## Endpoint
`PUT /posts/{id}`

- **Base URL (local)**: `http://127.0.0.1:8000`
- **Example**: `PUT http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts/7`

## Purpose
Use this endpoint to fully update an existing blog post’s title and content. The record is identified by the `id` path parameter.

## URL Parameters
- **id** (path, integer, required)
  - The unique identifier of the blog post to update.
  - Example: `7`

## Authentication
- **Type**: Bearer token (JWT access token)
- **Header**:
  - `Authorization: Bearer <your_access_token>`
- Requests without a valid token will typically be rejected with an authorization error (e.g., 401/403).

## Request Headers
- `Content-Type: application/json`

## Request Body
Send a JSON object with the updated fields.

### Schema
```json
{
  "title": "string",
  "content": "string"
}
```

### Field Details
- **title** (string, required)
  - New title for the blog post.
  - Example values: `"My family photo"`, `"just testing"`.

- **content** (string, required)
  - Updated content/body of the blog post.
  - Example values: `"content changed for testing"`, `"updation done"`.

### Example Payload
```json
{
  "title": "testing post",
  "content": "upadted"
}
```

## Successful Response (200 OK)
On success, the API returns HTTP **200 OK** and a JSON object representing the updated post, including metadata.

### Example 200 Response
```json
{
  "id": 7,
  "title": "testing post",
  "content": "upadted",
  "comments": [],
  "author": 4,
  "created_at": "2025-12-19T12:11:50.653261Z",
  "updated_at": "2025-12-19T12:11:50.653261Z"
}
```

- `id`: ID of the updated post.
- `comments`: List of associated comments (empty array if none).
- `author`: The user ID of the author.
- `created_at` / `updated_at`: Timestamps in ISO 8601 format.

request.description:
### Delete a Blog Post by ID

This endpoint deletes a single blog post identified by its numeric ID.

- **Method:** `DELETE`
    
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts/{id}`
    
    - Example in this request: `http://127.0.0.1:8000/posts/7`
        

### Authorization

This operation requires an authenticated user.

- **Auth type:** Bearer token (JWT access token)
    
- **Header:**
    
    - `Authorization: Bearer`
        

If the token is missing, expired, or invalid, the API will return an authorization error (4xx).

### Request

- **Path parameter:**
    
    - `id` (integer, required) — ID of the post to delete.
        
- **Request body:** Not required for this DELETE request.
    

### Responses & Examples

This request has saved examples that illustrate typical outcomes:

1. **Post deleted successfully**
    
    - Example: **“post deleted by user id and post 7”**
        
    - Indicates that the authenticated user successfully deleted post with ID `7`.
        
    - Typical status: `204 No Content` (or `200 OK` with a confirmation payload, depending on implementation).
        
2. **Post not found**
    
    - Example: **“deleted post not found”**
        
    - Returned when the specified `id` does not correspond to an existing post (already deleted or never existed).
        
    - Typical status: `404 Not Found`.
        

### Usage Notes

- Ensure you are sending a valid JWT access token in the `Authorization` header.
    
- Only authorized users (for example, the owner of the post or an admin, depending on your backend rules) are allowed to delete posts.
    
- Use the **“post deleted by user id and post 7”** example to see the expected behavior for a successful delete, and **“deleted post not found”** to understand the not-found scenario.

request.description:
Retrieves all comments in the blog application.

**Endpoint**
- **Method:** `GET`
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/comments`

**Successful Response (200 OK)**
Returns a JSON array of comment objects. Each comment has the following fields:

```json
[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "post": 1,
    "author": 2,
    "content": "nice family",
    "created_at": "2025-12-10T10:31:43.149917Z",
    "updated_at": "2025-12-10T10:31:43.149917Z"
  }
]
```

**Field descriptions**
- `id` (integer): Unique identifier for the comment.
- `post` (integer): ID of the post this comment belongs to.
- `author` (integer): ID of the user who created the comment.
- `content` (string): The text content of the comment.
- `created_at` (string, ISO 8601): Timestamp when the comment was created.
- `updated_at` (string, ISO 8601): Timestamp of the last update to the comment.

**Usage notes**
- Use this endpoint to list all comments, for example to display them in an admin dashboard or for debugging.
- No request body or query parameters are required for a basic fetch of all comments.

request.description:
### Create Comment for Blog Post

Creates a new comment for a specific blog post.

#### Request
- **Method:** `POST`
- **URL:** `http://127.0.0.1:8000/comments`
- **Authentication:** Requires an authenticated user (the `author` field in the response is derived from the authenticated user).
- **Body Type:** `raw` JSON

#### Request Body (JSON)
```json
{
  "content": "testing comment for post and user ",
  "post": 8
}
```

**Required fields:**
- `content` (string): The text content of the comment.
- `post` (integer): The ID of the blog post this comment belongs to.

#### Successful Response
- **Status:** `201 Created`

**Response Body (JSON)**
```json
{
  "id": 5,
  "post": 8,
  "author": 4,
  "content": "testing comment for post and user",
  "created_at": "2025-12-20T07:44:05.789364Z",
  "updated_at": "2025-12-20T07:44:05.789364Z"
}
```

**Response fields:**
- `id` (integer): Unique identifier of the comment.
- `post` (integer): ID of the associated blog post.
- `author` (integer): ID of the user who created the comment.
- `content` (string): Text content of the comment.
- `created_at` (string, datetime): Timestamp when the comment was created.
- `updated_at` (string, datetime): Timestamp when the comment was last updated.
